page.title: 17Old Village School
page.content: Old school in Crayke was opened on New Years DAy 1846, from the design of Mr Jones, architect, York. The opening day was celebrated by a service in the Village Church (it was the Festival of the Circumcision). At 12 the school room was prepared with a feast including plum pudding and roast beef for the thirty seven girls and thirty five boys. The school building was paid for by Rev Churton, Dr Whytehead and other benevolent individuals for the free education of boys. It closed on 23 March 1973 when a new school was built on Easingwold Rd. The old school is now used as a village hall and play group. Some of the names which came up on the old register which are still in school, or in the village today, are Gilleard, Knowles, Leckenby, Jackson and Dennis.
